Title: [WIP] Albatros: CPU/GPU shared variable #130
Description:
fixes #130 

Right now I am trying to debug my fix to work with the theano/tensor/tests/test_sharedvar.py unit tests. Have some topo errors that I don't really understand:

For this PR:
- [x] Fix don't change the shared var outside type during execution
- [ ] Use an internal variable with a type different then the outside variable type. Here we can force all Theano function to use the same internal type for a given shared variable. That way, we don't need to do automatic transfer between CPU and GPU.
- [ ] Add tests that check pickling/unpickling with changing GPU availability.
- [ ] don't have strange dependency on cuda in tensor

For another PR:
- [ ] support new GPU back-end
- [ ] Figure out how to have the shared variable be considered on different device in different Theano function.

Title: Kernel precomp
Description:
I've tested this through the GpuEye Op which uses GpuKernelBase, and it seems to work great.

This speeds up gpu code initialization (when loading modules from cache) and allows the user to get compile errors for his kernel source during the compile phase (rather than at module load time).

There is backward compat code that will attempt to recompile the kernel from source should the binary initialization fail (and it always does on some platform/device combinations).

Title: Renamed "copy_inputs" into "share_inputs" in clone
Description:
Old argument "copy_inputs" still works but will show a deprecation
warning.

The reason is that "copy_inputs" suggests that inputs are copied, while
actually they are not.

Title: Fixed error message for scan op dimension mismatch
Description:
The error message when the scan op has a dimension mismatch prints a dimension which is 1 higher than the dimension compared, which results in cryptic errors such as:

```
The initial state (outputs_info in scan nomenclature) of variable X (argument number 0)
has dtype float32 and 3 dimension(s), while the result of the inner function for this output
has dtype float32 and 3 dimension(s).
```

NEWS.txt:
-better error msg: (Bart)

Title: Gpua rng opt
Description:
Add optimization to move an mrg_uniform op to the GPU.

This is currently somewhat fragile because the graph actually needs the opt to work (as in it won't compile if device=cuda0 and the opt is not run for some reason).

Also, don't try to test it on cuda gpus without this fix for libgpuarray: https://github.com/Theano/libgpuarray/pull/7, or you'll get some weird out of memory error in GpuArray_init.

Title: [ENH] Hermitian generalized eigenvalues and gradient
Description:
This is a new function to sandbox.linalg for generalized eigenvalues of a hermitian positive definite eigenproblems, using scipy.linalg.eigh. And also the gradients of the eigenvalues.

I asked about this on the [mailing list](https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/theano-dev/WZU5quAzxsA) a couple weeks ago, but this is my first PR for theano, so I'm not really sure if I'm doing everything correctly.

But that seems very inelegant.

Title: Shape check input
Description:
news:
- Compile less C modules.
- Add Theano flags check_inputs=True. If False, won't check node inputs in c code. It can be used to speed up compilation, reduce overhead (particularly for scalars) and reduce the number of generated C files.

Internal:
- Add optional Op.check_inputs attribute, if False, as flag check_inputs, but for this op only and it is always the case.

Title: FFT convolution: make optimization support uneven image width
Description:
Hey,

this is a collection of a few minor fixes/enhancements regarding `conv2d_fft` (by the way, thanks a lot to Sander for starting it and to everybody else involved in making this happen!):
- For me, `nosetests theano/sandbox/cuda/tests/test_fftconv.py` always resulted in a failure because `test_full` happened to be executed before `test_opt_full` or `test_opt_valid`, so `theano.sandbox.cuda.fftconv` hadn't been imported by anybody yet. Fixed by explicitly importing it in the beginning of the file. Let me know if the import needs to be conditional instead and I'll change it.
- It was a bit cumbersome to find out that I don't only need `scikits.cuda`, but even the current development version. Documented that.
- While reading the code, I noticed that `ConvOp` allows an image and filter shape specification with some entries set to `None` to indicate that they are not known at compile time. This is passed on to `GpuConv` in the `local_gpu_conv` optimizer, but `GpuConv` assumed it either had no shape specification or a fully qualified shape specification. Added an extra check where needed.
- When using the `conv_fft_valid` and `conv_fft_full` optimizers on a graph that had convolution input images with uneven image width, it would happily create a graph that doesn't run (i.e., it compiles, but barks when executed). Changed the optimizers to check for uneven image width if the image width was given at compile time, and use the `pad_last_dim` argument to `conv2d_fft()` if needed.

Sorry for putting this in a single pull request, I can split things if needed.

Cheers, Jan

Title: The -ccbin argument to nvcc has to be a direct argument to nvcc
Description:
Currently the -ccbin argument gets placed in the list of arguments in -Xcompiler instead of being an argument directly to `nvcc`

Using CUDA6.0 on OSX 10.8.5 with clang `import theano` fails. After some googling I found the recommendation to add:

```
[nvcc]
flags=-ccbin=/usr/bin/clang
```

to my `.theanorc`. However this add the `ccbin=...` command line option in the wrong place.

Starting up a new python instance with `THEANO_FLAGS='floatX=float32,device=gpu'  ipython` and typing `import theano` leads to the following:

```
nvcc warning : The 'compute_10' and 'sm_10' architectures are deprecated, and may be removed in a future release.
clang: error: unsupported option '-dumpspecs'
clang: error: no input files

['nvcc', '-shared', '-g', '-O3', '-m64', '-Xcompiler', '-ccbin=/usr/bin/clang,-DCUDA_NDARRAY_CUH=d67f7c8a21306c67152a70a88a837011,-fPIC', '-Xlinker', '-rpath,/Users/thead/.theano/compiledir_Darwin-12.5.0-x86_64-i386-64bit-i386-2.7.5-64/cuda_ndarray', '-I/Users/thead/virtualenvs/default2/lib/python2.7/site-packages/theano/sandbox/cuda', '-I/Users/thead/virtualenvs/default2/lib/python2.7/site-packages/numpy/core/include', '-I/usr/local/Cellar/python/2.7.5/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/include/python2.7', '-o', '/Users/thead/.theano/compiledir_Darwin-12.5.0-x86_64-i386-64bit-i386-2.7.5-64/cuda_ndarray/cuda_ndarray.so', 'mod.cu', '-LNone/lib', '-lcublas', '-lcudart', '-L/usr/local/Cellar/python/2.7.6_1/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/lib/python2.7/config', '-ldl', '-lpython2.7', '-Xcompiler', '-framework,CoreFoundation', '-Xlinker', '-pie']
ERROR (theano.sandbox.cuda): Failed to compile cuda_ndarray.cu: ('nvcc return status', 1, 'for cmd', 'nvcc -shared -g -O3 -m64 -Xcompiler -ccbin=/usr/bin/clang,-DCUDA_NDARRAY_CUH=d67f7c8a21306c67152a70a88a837011,-fPIC -Xlinker -rpath,/Users/thead/.theano/compiledir_Darwin-12.5.0-x86_64-i386-64bit-i386-2.7.5-64/cuda_ndarray -I/Users/thead/virtualenvs/default2/lib/python2.7/site-packages/theano/sandbox/cuda -I/Users/thead/virtualenvs/default2/lib/python2.7/site-packages/numpy/core/include -I/usr/local/Cellar/python/2.7.5/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/include/python2.7 -o /Users/thead/.theano/compiledir_Darwin-12.5.0-x86_64-i386-64bit-i386-2.7.5-64/cuda_ndarray/cuda_ndarray.so mod.cu -LNone/lib -lcublas -lcudart -L/usr/local/Cellar/python/2.7.6_1/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/lib/python2.7/config -ldl -lpython2.7 -Xcompiler -framework,CoreFoundation -Xlinker -pie')
WARNING (theano.sandbox.cuda): CUDA is installed, but device gpu is not available
```

This PR fixes that by recognising -ccbin= as something that should be a preargs1. After this `import theano` works.

Title: Fix bizzare initialization code for cuda and yet another problem with cublas init.
Description:
The latest fix has introduced another problem, this time with device=gpu.

Since we don't even call gpu_init() in that case, the cublas handle never gets initialized.  It split out the testint part in a new gpu_test() function and rewrote the gpu_init() function to always initialize the blas handle.

This is not tested because it is late and I'm tired.  So please test before merging.

I hope this is the end of the troubles with that part.

Title: Faster algorithms and gradients for GpuCorrMM
Description:
As a follow-up to #2023, this PR adds [caffe's backward pass wrt. inputs](https://github.com/BVLC/caffe/blob/master/src/caffe/layers/conv_layer.cu#L98) to GpuCorrMM to implement `border_mode="full"`. It passes all the tests and it's about 2-4x faster than simulating a full convolution with a padded valid convolution. On the way, it cleans up the code and adds some more elaborate documentation.

There are some caveats, though, all stemming from the fact that the implementation in caffe is meant as a backward pass for a valid correlation:
- With `border_mode="valid"`, `GpuCorrMM` doesn't flip the kernels, but with `border_mode="full"`, it does.
- With `border_mode="valid"`, `subsampling` is for subsampling the output, but with `border_mode="full"`, it is for upsampling the input.
- With `border_mode="valid"`, `pad` is for padding the input, but with `border_mode="full"`, it is for cropping the output.
- With `border_mode="full"`, it needs a different memory layout for the kernels.

Currently, `GpuCorrMM` directly wraps the underlying algorithm, and `local_conv_gemm()` copes with the different peculiarities, because I wasn't sure whether the `GpuCorrMM` Op should be inserting dimshuffles, kernel flips and `gpu_contiguous`es on its own.

Looking at the end result, although it's quite fast, `local_conv_gemm()` now basically undoes everything that `ConvOp.grad()` does. It might be possible to write an optimizer that replaces the gradient of a valid convolution with a properly parameterized `GpuCorrMM` Op, instead of just replacing the full convolution Op that is part of the gradient (introducing redundant dimshuffles etc. on the way). This way we would leverage the caffe implementation better.
The alternative would be to modify the CUDA code to perform a subsampled, padded, full correlation, as would be expected from a Gpu Correlation Op. This would be cleaner, but it would also mean a lot more work and we wouldn't profit as much from caffe's implementation for the case of `subsampling != (1,1)` or `padding != (0,0)` (granted, this may be an uninteresting case in practice anyway).
/edit: Another alternative would be splitting this into two Ops: `GpuCorrMM` for valid correlation with padding and subsampling (the caffe forward pass), and `GpuConvMM` for full convolution with upsampling and cropping (the caffe backward pass). This way it would be obvious how the operations differ, but the memory layout required for the second Op would still be unintuitive.
Yet another alternative would be splitting it into `GpuCorrMM` and `GpuCorrMM_gradInput`. This way it would be obvious how to use `GpuCorrMM_gradInput` for computing the gradient of `GpuCorrMM`. We could even add `GpuCorrMM_gradKernel` for the gradient wrt. weights; it seems caffe does things slightly different there as well.
In both cases, `GpuCorrMM` should get a `grad()` method to define its gradient (so it can be used directly in a CNN to avoid kernel flipping and whatnot) and `local_conv_gemm()` should still be able to replace any `GpuConv` instances with a gemm-based Op (so it can be used with existing CNN implementations).

For the moment most of the "tests" fail due to various problems.  I fixed the the `library/tensor/basic.txt` file as a sample of the work that would have to be done to make this work for all the documentation.

If there is interest in this I can either work on it in this branch and merge when it's over or merge this right away to allow others to help.

When we get to a state where those tests pass we can think of adding such a test run to the buildbot and/or travis to check for broken examples and remove the test_tutorial files.

Title: Added option to not print inner scan graphs in printing.debugprint()
Description:
Here's a first stab at the issue. Fixes #2079

For now, I set the default values for the new parameters of printing.debugprint() and debugmode.debugprint() so that the default behavior is the same as right now (which is printing the inner graphs). This is, however, inconsistent with printing.pydotprint() where the default behavior is to not print the inner graphs.  This is mostly a consistent interface vs coherent interface question and if anyone has a strong opinion on this, I'm listening.
Events: lamblin closed 2014-10-01 21:49:59,carriepl head_ref_deleted 2014-12-16 14:29:38

Title: Propagate shape information to ConvOp gradients
Description:
Another attempt at closing #2089, as an alternative to #2095.

I just went through `theano/tensor/nnet/conv.py` from top to bottom trying to understand and clean up the shape inference code. Changes are:
- In `has_all_shape()`, `nkern` and `bsize` default to `1` so they can be omitted to just check for completeness of `imshp` and `kshp`.
- `getOutputShape()` supports symbolic shapes and shapes including `None`s. Also it returns a tuple instead of a numpy array.
- `imshp`, `kshp`, `imshp_logical`, `kshp_logical`, `outshp` and `fulloutshp` are guaranteed to be tuples after `__init__()` was called, but can contain `None`s. All the code is adapted to this.

I just tested this with `theano/sandbox/cuda/test_conv_cuda_ndarray.py:test_gemm_grads` and found that I had to disable shape inference (`infer_shape()`) by unconditionally raising a `ShapeError` for it to work. So probably something is wrong, but I cannot look into this today. Regard this as "under construction", but let me know if you have any comments.

Title: Add new flag for theano profiling output cropping
Description:
Fixes #2080 . This pull requests adds a new flag, profiling.output_line_width, which can be set to limit the line length of the profiling output. Its default value is 512.

The change is the way the variables maxlen are computed is to avoid an invalid behavior when line_width is smaller than upto_length.

Title: add support for border_mode='half' to cudnn
Description:
Following up on #2118, I added support for a 'half' `border_mode` to the cudnn convolution implementation. I didn't want to call it 'same' because it only gives the same output feature map dimensionality if the filter sizes are odd. If they are even, the output feature map dimensionality is one larger than the input.

For example:
input shape (64, 128, 32, 32), filter shape (256, 128, **5**, **5**) will result in an output shape of (64, 256, **32**, **32**)
input shape (64, 128, 32, 32), filter shape (256, 128, **6**, **6**) will result in an output shape of (64, 256, **33**, **33**)

Unfortunately implementing a true 'same' convolution is a bit more involved and the definition is a bit ambiguous.

I also had a look into adding some tests for this, but it seems that tests for convolutions with different border modes are a bit involved, so I haven't attempted this yet. It looks like I'd have to add a `_test_half` function in `test_conv_cuda_ndarray.py`?

Title: Include and library flags in nvcc.flags in config not passed to nvcc correctly
Description:
Note: I am working on the win32 platform.
Include and library flags given to nvcc.flags in the theano.rc config file are not passed to nvcc correctly; they come through separated by commas instead of spaces. (e.g. '-LC:\\packages\\cudnn,-IC:\\packages\\cudnn' instead of '-LC:\\packages\\cudnn -IC:\\packages\\cudnn').
I have made a small fix that adds '-I' and '-L' to the list of patterns that are filtered into the 'preargs1' list in the NVCC_compiler.compile_str() method.

Title: Fix blocksparse optimization that could give bad results in some cases
Description:
This changes the way "inplace" optimization for SparseBlock{Gemv,Outer}SS works.  It makes it much safer for unusual graphs and add support for add along with sub.

However due to these changes, it makes avoiding the Alloc the responsability of other optimizations (local_alloc_elemwise), which are not enabled by default and are highly recommended.  Use the flag `optimizer_including=local_alloc_elemwise` to enable it.

Title: Dot optimization
Description: This is a generalization of the proposed optimization T.dot(A, B)[i] --> T.dot(A[i], B) to deal with multiple indices. For example, if A and B are matrices then T.dot(A, B)[:, i] will become T.dot(A, B[:, i]), and similarly for tensors and more indices. The tests have not yet been written.

Title: Adding new superclass for C ops
Description: This adds a new class (gof.COp) for new C ops to inherit from. It allows to have the C implementation in a different file than the Python implementation and it also takes care of a few C-related methods of the Op class automatically. This pull request also updates the Extending Theano with a C Op tutorial to include an example using this new class.

Title: Add a mechanism to use more than one (gpu) context in a single theano function
Description:
**Disclaimer:** This is work in progress.  Some changes made here will cause a lot of code to not work anymore, so don't use this branch unless you are prepared to deal with that.

This add some optional methods on Ops that will trigger CLinker to pass a context argument that will be available at init and runtime.  This context is typed according to the the type specified by the op.

Also this makes the context a part of the theano Type for GpuArray.  This way, most Ops will know what context they are going to work with and it makes it easy for the context to propagate through the graph.

TODO:
- [x] Trivial example with 2 dots on different GPUs.
- [x] Fix crash with tests/optimizations.
- [x] add a way to copy a buffer from one context to another (without passing thought the CPU)
- [x] Fix crash with tests/optimizations and non default context.
- [x] add a way to specify the context of the inputs. (probably a tag with the context name)
- [x] gpu to gpu transfer _as_GpuArrayVariabl
- [ ] replicate Alex models?

Title: Using DONE_SET method to make algorithm faster
Description: What we do is like to maintain a dict {DONE_SET: memory peak}, then Each time when we execute Node X, we make a check if the peak in dict and the current peak bigger than that peak. If yes(or equal), break and start a new branch. if no, update the peak in dict and continue.

However, we don't have any test to check the formatting of Theano files (like test_format.py in Pylearn2), but maybe we should have it at some point?
- Julian

Title: stdint should not be imported into OpenCL kernels
Description:
Key change : OpenCL doesn't need the same type information to be included in kernels (in particular, including files _at all_ is somewhat deprecated : http://devgurus.amd.com/message/1296050)

This PR should cure the failure of the opencl test script shown on http://deeplearning.net/software/theano/tutorial/using_gpu.html

The code has been before/after tested on my Linux OpenCL system (with an Nvidia graphics card, but no CUDA libraries installed).  For non-OpenCL systems, the gpuarray output should be unchanged.

The PR also solves the central issue behind "Theano fails when device=opencl #2189" (where the bug is correctly identified, and a PR is asked for, but the issue was closed because it wasn't clear that libgpuarray hadn't been 'messed with').

Also this should fix:
"stdint.h not found error on MacOS Mavericks when running theano test on OpenCL using libgpuarray" found at https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/theano-users/4HrFKsL5c2w

If this is acceptable, I'd be happy to continue ploughing ahead with OpenCL/gpuarray fixes (since, FWIW, OpenCL is more appealing to this Linux user than CUDA...)

Title: Scan opt to push out Dot products outside of Scan's inner graph
Description:
This is still work in progress. Since dealing with Scan is non-trivial, I just want the opportunity to get some feedback to make sure I'm not going in the wrong direction. At the very least, I still have to do the following : 
- Document the code further
- Add tests to validate that the optimization is applied properly

This scan optimization covers the following case : 
- One of the inner graph's output is produced by a Dot operation
- The Dot's inputs are a 2D non-sequence input to scan and a 1D tensor produced by scan's inner function

In the covered case, the optimization adds the 1D intermediate variable as a new scan output and performs the Dot outside of Scan with this new output.

On CPU (i7-950) with input sizes (500,) and (500, 500), the following function
a = T.vector()
b = T.matrix()
c = T.dot(a, b)
f = theano.function([a, b], T.jacobian(c, a))
goes from taking 0.06 seconds to 0.03 seconds by execution (averaged over 100 runs)

Title: Slightly clean up registration of GPU convolution optimizers
Description:
As discussed [on theano-dev](https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/theano-dev/QEB-KAaMT-Q), this changes the registration of GPU-based convolution optimizers in the following way:
- The optimizer moving convolutions to GPU is pulled out of the `LocalGroupDB` named `conv_groupopt` in sandbox/cuda/opt.py
- `conv_groupopt` now only includes the optimizers replacing the legacy convolution with alternative implementations; they are registered via a group so they are tried in a specific order and we can control which ones to prefer.
- The tags they are registered with do not include the `local_` prefix any more. They are user-facing, so they should be user-friendly. The two FFT-related optimizers are registered under a common tag `conv_fft` to make it easier to include or exclude them.
- The `local_conv_dnn` optimizer of sandbox/cuda/dnn.py is only registered as part of `conv_groupopt`, not on its own any more. Otherwise we lose control over the order the optimizers are tried in.

If you're fine with the tags, let me know and I'll update the documentation accordingly in a separate commit.

Title: Fix cuDNN detection
Description:
The cuDNN detection code in `theano.sandbox.cuda.dnn.dnn_available()` is slightly broken. It assumes that cuda.h, cudnn.h and cudnn.so are available in standard system-wide include and library directories, while during the compilation of the cuDNN ops, it is enough if they are available in CUDA's include and library directories.
This PR includes cuda.h before cudnn.h to not give a "cudnn.h is not found" error if even cuda.h cannot be found (to avoid pointing the user in the wrong direction on what to fix). In addition, it adds the CUDA include and lib directories to the GCC call via -I and -L, respectively.

Alternatively, the check could just use nvcc instead of gcc, but I don't know if that's easy to accomplish.

Title: conv2d meta-optimizer
Description:
This is a basic implementation of meta-optimization (#2072) for GPU-based convolutions. The idea of meta-optimization is to automatically choose the best-performing implementation of several alternatives provided by regular graph optimizers.

It introduces a local optimizer base class that for each node it is asked to replace, tries all local optimizers registered with it to determine which is the fastest, then chooses that. To time an implementation, it needs to be compiled into a function and run. This in turn requires non-symbolic inputs for the Apply node to be optimized. Inputs that are shared variables have data associated with them, so they can be used directly. Inputs that have a test value attached are replaced by shared variables of that value. Any other inputs need to be taken care of by subclasses of the base class.
For convolution, I make use of the fact that Apply nodes often know the expected input shape, so we can create random input data of the correct shape to compile the functions (see `ConvMetaOptimizers.provide_inputs()`).

Currently, the meta-optimizer is turned on by setting `THEANO_FLAGS=optimizer_including=conv_meta`. It then tries all convolution optimizers currently available in Theano (cudnn, gemm, and fft) regardless of whether they are active or not. It currently does not include the legacy convolution in the timing, because this usually just slows everything down. Additional optimizers (e.g., for cuda-convnet) can be registered at runtime via its `register` method (e.g., `theano.sandbox.cuda.opt.conv_metaopt.register(my_own_optimizer)`).

This PR can be merged as is. The following should be addressed in future:
- I would prefer to have it try only the optimizers that are active (i.e., cudnn and gemm if they haven't been deactivated, and fft only if it has been activated), is there an easy way to do so?
- For gemm, it should try both `GpuCorrMM` and `GpuCorrMM_gradWeights` if both are applicable, not rely on the heuristic in `local_conv_gemm`.
- Timings should be cached on disk to speed up repeated invocations.
- A second meta-optimizer for pooling could be added, once we have enough competing implementations.

Title: Fixes a crash of casting bytes to Python string
Description: The crash happened when cuDNN isn't used and the error message was raised. However, the message was a 'bytes' object, not a string. Casting the bytes to string solves the issue.

Title: Make automatic insertions of dnn_conv() use the optimal cuDNN code path
Description:
To address #2268, this PR changes `dnn_conv()` and the accompanying graph optimizers to not replace all `GpuConv` ops with `GpuConvDnn`, but use `GpuConvDnnGradI` and `GpuConvDnnGradW` when appropriate.

This is work in progress; for now it just uses `GpuConvDnnGradI` for full convolutions and doesn't touch anything else. Getting the correct shape for the convolution descriptor (and keeping it symbolic) was a bit cumbersome. I'll try to finish this sometime tomorrow.

Title: Make automatic insertions of dnn_conv() use the optimal cuDNN code path (2)
Description:
Continuation of #2272 that has already been merged.

This also chooses between GpuDnnConv and GpuDnnConvGradW depending on what the original purpose of the convolution was in the graph. For me the gradient wrt. weights is faster than before, but still quite a bit slower than manually using GpuDnnConv. I cannot look into this any more today, but if anyone wants to have a try, please go ahead. The goal would be to find out if it's slower because of extra dimshuffles/copies, or because I did something wrong. Please don't merge before investigating this, and also don't merge before re-running tests.

Title: Add grad() to GpuDnnConvGrad* ops
Description:
With #2272 and #2273, `dnn_conv()` can insert `GpuDnnConvGradI` and `GpuDnnConvGradW` instead of `GpuDnnConv`. Now if a user uses `dnn_conv()` to introduce a non-strided full convolution into a graph, it will be based on `GpuDnnConvGradI`, which doesn't have a gradient defined. This PR adds the necessary gradients of gradients.

I'm quite sure everything is correct, but I cannot get `nosetests -s theano/sandbox/cuda/tests/test_conv_cuda_ndarray.py:test_conv_grads` to pass, there are some broadcast pattern problems (and just enforcing the old pattern in local_conv_dnn() brings up new problems of the "Some CudaNdarray has dim 4 on broadcastable dimension 0" flavor). Can anyone confirm this / solve this?

Title: Reduce the number of allocation/reuse allocation of ndarray #1943
Description:
Note about this PR before merging:
- This is the first step of gh-1943. If the Loop or LoopGC VM get used and allow_gc is False and no lazy operation, we will reuse some intermediate memory storage. We do this by making the storage_map of some variable point to the same list. We carefully check which variable can be shared. This make that some thunk will have there output available when they run.
- Currently this is done only for variable where ndim == 0. A follow up ticket will generalize this.

Title: [ENH] Matrix exponential op and gradient (round 2!)
Description:
- Adds a new matrix exponential Op to slinalg.py, implemented with scipy.linalg.expm.
- Adds an op for the gradient of the matrix exponential.

This is a reworking of #2285. I fixed the math. It works for general (non-necessarily hermetian) arguments. [This test](https://github.com/rmcgibbo/Theano/blob/expm/theano/tensor/tests/test_slinalg.py#L273-L280) is with an arbitrary 5x5 matrix, without the restriction to symmetric matricies or anything.

Title: Scan push out sum of dot
Description:
This is work in progress to implement to optimization necessary to push a "Sum of dots" out of a scan. It is **not** ready for merge because the optimization doesn't get applied in the unit test TestPushOutSumOfDot.test_non_zero_init() which means that there is currently no test for the case where the initial value of the scan output to which the dot products are added is non-zero.

The optimization is, however, correctly applied in the TestPushOutSumOfDot.test_machine_translation() test case which comes from from https://github.com/rizar/scan-grad-speed

This also includes some refactoring of the optimization PushOutScanOutput to make the code simpler and more readable and also factor out the bits of code that are common between the different use cases of the optimization.

Title: Convert SetSubtensor to IncSubtensor when possible
Description:
This came up in a user case where decoupling led to code doing essentially this:

```
v = <some value>
s = v[[2, 1]]
g = s + 1
r = set_subtensor(s, g)
```

In this case the set_subtensor is actually an inc_subtensor in disguise.

I only cover the AdvancedSubtensor1 case in this PR as that was the problem, but this could be extended to the other kind of indexing.

Title: now pretty print works for scaler variables too.
Description:
Hi @dwf ,
Here I just handle output[0] of a FunctionGraph in a Composite.
I'm now sure how should I print multiple outputs.
I'm still struggling with a good test file. The only thing I found is this test:

import numpy
import theano

def detect_nan(i, node, fn):
    for output in fn.outputs:
        if numpy.isnan(output[0]).any():
            print '**\\* NaN detected ***'
            theano.printing.debugprint(node)
            print 'Inputs : %s' % [input[0] for input in fn.inputs]
            print 'Outputs: %s' % [output[0] for output in fn.outputs]
            break

x = theano.tensor.dscalar('x')
f = theano.function([x], [theano.tensor.log(x) \\* x],
                    mode=theano.compile.MonitorMode(
                        post_func=detect_nan))
f(0)

Title: Add breakpoint Op to Theano
Description:
This is just a small utility class to allow a user to put a conditional breakpoint, with pdb, inside the execution of a Theano function. It is implemented in a similar way to the Print() op in that it's a identity-like op with a side effect. It takes multiple inputs and the first one needs to be a 0d tensor and is interpreted as the condition that will decide the activation of the breakpoint. When, during execution, that condition is evaluated to True, the breakpoint will be activated. The subsequent inputs are interpreted as the variables the user wants to monitor and will be made available to the user when the conditional breakpoint activates.

I am not sure what the best way to test this class would be. It is easy enough to test that the breakpoint doesn't activate in a particular case but testing that it does activate seems a little bit more subtle.

Title: Lower the number of disk access: continuation
Description:
This is a continuation of gh-2460. The only diff is the last commit.

I separate it as it is more controversial. I reimplement traceback.extract_stack() and disable its line that cause call to os.stat. This is to speed up access in particular on cluster.

I checked cpython dev version (version ~3.5). The code is different, but seem very similar. I think that this PR version of that function is compatiable, but I haven't tested it. As this is internal stuff of cpython, I enable it only for python 2.7. If we see it working with other version, we can enable it.

Title: WIP : Push scan computation inside inner function
Description:
This is a work in progress to push overhead computation done by scan into its inner function. As of now, the change has been done for input sequences and I am working on doing the same for the inputs associated with recurring outputs (sitsots, mitsots, mitmots).

An ImportError is now raised at line (for now) 583 to force scan to use the python function execute instead of the Cython implementation. Title: Fixing Split docstring
Description:
Currently, Split's docstring has the example

``` Python
        x = vector()
        splits = lvector()
        # you have to declare right away how many split_points there will be.
        ra, rb, rc = split(x, splits, n_splits = 3, axis = 0)

        f = function([x, splits], [ra, rb, rc])

        a, b, c = f([0,1,2,3,4,5,6], [3, 2, 1])

        #a == [0,1,2]
        #b == [3, 4]
        #c == [5]
```

This leads to the following error:

```
ValueError: The splits sum to 6, expected 7
```

This fixes that.

Title: Fix equilibrium opt error recently introduced
Description:
A PR introduced the shape_to_shape_i opt in the GPU opt. But this cause this opt to get called too often with the default equilibrium max_use_ratio.

We fix this. This caused tests like theano/sandbox/cuda/tests/test_conv_cuda_ndarray.py:test_full to raise errors.

I think it is bad for opt to introduce to ugly graph as this cause too much work for the optimizer. This allow optimizer to introduce less work for futur optimizer.

Title: Adding GpuSplit op to cuda submodule
Description:
As discussed here (towards the end):
https://groups.google.com/forum/#!searchin/theano-users/GpuSplit/theano-users/ZDuZkFvnEfI/eNe-NuZJibMJ
GpuSplit needs to be ported to the new GPU backend.  This adds the GpuSplit op and an accompanying optimization.  

I had to change the `perform` method in the Theano basic tensor `Split` class. It was calling `__getitem__` on `x` with a list argument which caused a `NotImplementedError` when `x` was a CudaNdarray.  So, I'm converting the index arg to a tuple first.  Thanks to @f0k for this.

This is my first op so please let me know if there's anything I'm doing wrong!  I got a lot of help on this from @f0k and @benanne.

Title: AdvancedSubtensor1 support for local_useless_subtensor optimization
Description:
I added `AdvancedSubtensor1` support for the `local_useless_subtensor` optimization where the following cases are optimized:
- `x[[0,1,...,#rows(x) - 1]] -> x` with a constant vector
- `x[T.arange(x.shape[0])] -> x`

I'm not sure if there is an `AdvancedSubtensor` case, too. The only one I could imagine would be `x[[0,0,...,1,1,...,#rows(x),#rows(x),...], [0,1,...,#cols(x),0,1,...,#cols(x),...]].reshape((#rows(x), #cols(x))` given `x` is a matrix (could be generalized for all tensors). Is this worth the effort? It seems like a very unlikely case, but I could do it if you feel it should be included. What I'm no clear about, though, is if that's actually a case for this optimization because the `AdvancedSubtensor` op will give a vector in any case. Only combined with `reshape` will this be a equivalent to just using `x` instead of the indexing + reshaping.

This is part of gh-2207
Events: nouiz referenced 2015-02-25 14:01:24,nouiz merged 2015-02-25 14:01:24,nouiz closed 2015-02-25 14:01:24,sisp head_ref_deleted 2015-02-25 14:40:05

Title: [MRG] New optimization: useless incsubtensor alloc
Description:
I found a missing optimization when looking at the following graph:

```
W = T.vector('W')
i = T.vector('i', dtype='int64')
t = T.scalar('t')
z = T.sqr(t - W[i].sum())
g = theano.grad(z, W)
f = theano.function([W, i, t], g)
theano.printing.pydotprint(f, 'graph.png', format='png')
```

![theano](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2206639/6320145/0e34a248-bad7-11e4-8d8e-2fbbac0e0633.png)
In the picture, "Alloc id=8" is unnecessary because the broadcastable scalar resulting from the fused elementwise ops is simply repeated, but `IncSubtensor` and `AdvancedIncSubtensor1` can broadcast a scalar increment automatically. I added a new optimization that fixes this case.

Comments?

Title: Speed up local useless subtensor
Description:
Refactor local_useless_subtensor to allow earlier exiting of the function
Add a parameter to Subtensor.get_constant_idx() to prevent calls to get_scalar_constant_value() which can result in constant folding.

With this modification, in FAST_RUN, the optimization phase in test_scan.py:T_Scan.test_hessian_bug_grad_grad_two_scans goes from ~6 minutes to ~4 minutes.

Title: [WIP] Mechanism for running a test multiple times with different random seeds
Description:
This PR defines a new decorator to achieve the objective named in the title and applies it on two tests that are known to randomly go over the accepted tolerance depending on the random seed they use.
Remaining in this PR is to identify and modify the other unit tests which need such a mechanism.
Also, for now, I parametrized the decorator so that it attempts 3 times and needs at least 2 successes. These might not be the best parameters and I'm open to opinions regarding how they should be set.

Title: [WIP] add equivalent of mgrid/ogrid functionality
Description:
With reference to [this discussion](https://groups.google.com/forum/#!msg/theano-users/ueOfrjiYvZA/TrqAMQSi8ewJ) here is, albeit a lot later than I would have liked, an implementation of the `numpy.mgrid/ogrid` functionality for `theano.tensor`.

The basic idea is already coded, along with some equivalence tests to the numpy functionality.

However, some questions remain:
- Do we want the "imaginary step sizes shorthand", which turns step size into _number of steps, endpoint included_. I find this behavior slightly scary in the theano context, so for now it is not implemented.
- I added a few rudimentary tests, but I am probably missing some standard catches to test for. Please comment if this is the case.
- I added a docstring for the `_ndgrid` class. However, `mgrid` and `ogrid` are instances of these classes and should have different docstrings explaining their functionality. In numpy this is solved by injecting docstrings a posteriori into these instances. Is there a standard for doing this in theano as well?
- Generally, I am not entirely familiar with coding conventions in theano. So if something stands out as weird, please yell. That way I'll learn :)

Title: Flatten C code
Description: I added C code to the `Flatten` op. @lamblin mentioned in another PR that it is desirable to avoid multiple C code variants per op. The current implementation is parameterized by `outdim` which will cause a precompiled module per `outdim` value. There are two options: 1) `outdim` remains a constructor argument but is fed to the `Apply` node in `make_node`. Thus, `outdim` would still have to be a constant value and it could be checked in `make_node` as it's done now. 2) `outdim` could become a proper input of the `Flatten` op which means it could change during runtime. It's probably a rare case that someone actually wants to do this. Then, the sanity checks in `make_node` would not be possible anymore in the general case. Which variant do you guys prefer?

Title: Fix connection_pattern and add test
Description:
Fixes #2594. As far as I can tell, the bug relied is that the code relied on self.get_input_pos(), which gives indices of **inner** inputs and used the results as if they were indices of **outer** inputs.

This fixes the bug that was raised on the theano-users mailing list but I am not sure it fixes every issue that could come up with connection_pattern. I have the impression (but I'm not 100% certain) that the code relies on the number of inner outputs and outer outputs being the same to work (mainly lines 1413-1417 after my changes) which is not guaranteed. Could one of @lamblin or @abergeron have a look and tell my what you think.

Title: strict mode to avoid nested scan
Description:
This addresses the findings from #2609 . 

If strict=True in theano.scan, it assumes that all necessary shared variables in fn are passed as a part of non_sequences.  This has to be ensured by the user. Otherwise, it'll result in an error. This avoids Scan Op calling any earlier (external) Op over and over, and greatly speeds up.

Title: Scan connection pattern
Description: Alter the method connection_pattern() in Scan to avoid calling the function grad() repeatedly. This aims to break the cycle that occurs with nested Scans where which calling scan.grad() will call connection_pattern() which will call tensor.grad() which will eventually call scan.grad() on the nested Scans.

Title: GpuAllocEmpty for dnn_conv()
Description:
This adds `GpuAllocEmpty`, makes `GpuAlloc` derive from it to avoid a lot of duplicated code, and makes `dnn_conv()` use `gpu_alloc_empty(*shape)` instead of `gpu_alloc(_zero.clone(), *shape)`. If merged, this partly solves #2632 (for GPU only).

I'm not sure about a few things:
1. Does `GpuAllocEmpty` need to implement `__eq__` and `__hash__` or does one of the base classes handle it already? (It seemed to me that the base class implementation only steps in if the class has a `__props__` member.)
2. What should `GpuAllocEmpty.do_constant_folding()` do? For now I always return `False`. I don't know anything about the constant folding machinery, though.
3. What's needed to make it work in DebugMode? The indeterministic output is problematic, I've heard?

Otherwise it seems to work fine (I don't have a free GPU to run all the tests right now).

PS: I intentionally didn't update `GpuAlloc.c_code_cache_version()` because the returned C code is exactly the same.

Title: Added a config variable to disable the GCC-based cuDNN compilation check
Description:
Added a config variable to disable the GCC-based cuDNN compilation check as it breaks on Windows with the GTX900 series CUDA 6.5 and CUDA 7.0.

When using the GTX900 series version of CUDA 6.5 from nVidia on the Windows platform, I have found that this breaks on two different machines, one on Win 8, the other on Win 7, while it _seemed to_ work okay on the non 900 series version (e.g. on an older card with a different CUDA 6.5 toolkit this hack was not necessary). Using CUDA toolkit 7.0 does not fix the issue.

The problem occurs at startup when Theano tests cuDNN with a simple GCC-based test. GCC fails to locate cuda.h:

```
AssertionError: cuDNN optimization was enabled, but Theano was not able to use it. We got this error:
Theano can not compile with cuDNN. We got this error:
c:\\users\\geoff\\appdata\\local\\temp\\try_flags_uk5iph.c:4:18: fatal error: cuda.h: No such file or directory
compilation terminated.
```

This simple hack allows you to put a config variable in your `.theanorc` that will skip this test, allowing Theano to proceed.

Title: Add numpy.compress to theano.tensor
Description:
Added `numpy.compress` to the `theano.TensorVariable` interface, including unit tests.
Ref. issue #1080

There is one problem with the implementation at the moment... which I haven't been able to resolve on my own.

Namely, it is that I cannot estimate the shape of outputs.
The input into `compress` is a vector of bools which represents whether an element/slice should be retained in the output, as well as the matrix being operated on.
I cannot retrieve the dimension of the condition vector.

Any advice/help would be appreciated.

Title: Autopep!
Description:
Since it was mentioned the other day that we want to start working towards PEP8 compliance, I figured I'd let `autopep8` loose on some of the easier errors to fix (spaces after/before `#`, `,`, operators, and too many/few blank lines) and see how it does.

This is a PR with the fixes that I think it applied perfectly without any strange artifacts. It leaves all the C code intact as far as I can tell, and reduces the number of PEP8 violations from 17296 to 9236. E501 and E128 are the two remaining major offenders, but although `autopep8` fixes them nicely in 90% of the cases, it sometimes ends up with some very strange line breaks, so I left those out.

It also brings the whitelist back up to date (some files were missing, and after the change some could be removed).

Let me know if you think is a good way to go, or whether you'd rather have CCW tickets for the next decade! :p

The top errors before `autopep8`:

```
318     E302 expected 2 blank lines, found 1
336     E225 missing whitespace around operator
353     E127 continuation line over-indented for visual indent
383     E261 at least two spaces before inline comment
412     E251 unexpected spaces around keyword / parameter equals
750     E402 module level import not at top of file
1793    E128 continuation line under-indented for visual indent
2278    E265 block comment should start with '# '
3806    E501 line too long (87 > 79 characters)
4233    E231 missing whitespace after ','
```

and afterwards

```
105     E502 the backslash is redundant between brackets
124     E122 continuation line missing indentation or outdented
194     E203 whitespace before ':'
211     W503 line break before binary operator
245     E129 visually indented line with same indent as next logical line
365     E265 block comment should start with '# '
366     E127 continuation line over-indented for visual indent
750     E402 module level import not at top of file
1811    E128 continuation line under-indented for visual indent
3863    E501 line too long (87 > 79 characters)
```

Title: Added support for negative axis in GpuCumsumOp
Description:
When a negative axis is provided to `GpuCumsumOp`, `CumsumOp` or `CumprodOp`, it will be converted to its positive equivalent (inferred from the given input array). 

Since the axis conversion happens during ~~the making of the node~~ the generation of the C code, two `cumsum` nodes created using a 2D array and respectively `axis=1` and `axis=-1` ~~will~~ won't be equivalent (their hash ~~will~~ won't be the same).~~

Closes #2715 

Edit: Saying two `cumsum` nodes with different axis may be equivalent was based on a wrong assumption.

Title: [CRASH] Fix crash in save_mem when directly using outputs of the scan node
Description:
This was found by unit tests in the Blocks framework.

The crash was caused by the save_mem optimization relying on the symbolic outputs of the scan() function being used by the user instead of of the outputs of the scan node. In blocks, they violate this assumption by taking the outputs of the scan() function and doing `x = x.owner.inputs[0]` on each of them to directly obtain the outputs of the scan node.

Title: Stop confusing inner and outer outputs in connection_pattern()
Description:
Based on the code and comments, the implementation of scan.connection_pattern appears to confuse inner and outer outputs. The method `get_input_pos()`, means to receive the index of an _inner_ output is called with the indices of _outer_ outputs. This means that if the scan has mitmot outputs with many output taps, some of its recurrent outputs might never be processed.

I tried to come up with a test case for this but couldn't find one where there would be a measurable, observable difference between the connection_pattern before this PR and after. I have a test case which I haven't included where the code behavior is different but the final connection_pattern is identical.

Title: Remove dependance on io_toposort in equal_computations()
Description:
Usage of toposort is replaced by parallel depth-first exploration of the two computational graphs. For Kratarth's use case (which admittedly uses huge scans) , it made calls to equal_computations roughly 200x faster.

I launched all the tests in scan_module/tests/, comparing the output between the old version of `equal_computations()` and the new. They agreed in all cases except in test case test_grad_multiple_outs_some_uncomputable on the graph : 

`[RandomFunction{uniform}(<RandomStateType>, TensorConstant{[]}, TensorConstant{-1.1}, TensorConstant{1.1}), Elemwise{mul,no_inplace}(TensorConstant{2}, u2[t]), RandomFunction{uniform}(<RandomStateType>, TensorConstant{[]}, TensorConstant{-1.1}, TensorConstant{1.1}), dot(u1[t], win_copy), DimShuffle{x}(RandomFunction{uniform}.1), Elemwise{add,no_inplace}(<TensorType(float64, (True,))>, dot.0), Elemwise{add,no_inplace}(Elemwise{add,no_inplace}.0, x0[t-1]), Elemwise{add,no_inplace}(Elemwise{add,no_inplace}.0, DimShuffle{x}.0)]`
and
`[RandomFunction{uniform}(<RandomStateType>, TensorConstant{[]}, TensorConstant{-1.1}, TensorConstant{1.1}), RandomFunction{uniform}(<RandomStateType>, TensorConstant{[]}, TensorConstant{-1.1}, TensorConstant{1.1}), Elemwise{mul,no_inplace}(TensorConstant{2}, u2[t]), dot(u1[t], win_copy), DimShuffle{x}(RandomFunction{uniform}.1), Elemwise{add,no_inplace}(<TensorType(float64, (True,))>, dot.0), Elemwise{add,no_inplace}(Elemwise{add,no_inplace}.0, x0[t-1]), Elemwise{add,no_inplace}(Elemwise{add,no_inplace}.0, DimShuffle{x}.0)]`

which the old implementation evaluated as non-equal (apparently, because the toposort returns the nodes in a different order) where as the new implementation says they are equal.
Events: lamblin mentioned 2015-04-20 15:45:13,lamblin subscribed 2015-04-20 15:45:13,lamblin referenced 2015-04-20 21:26:05,lamblin merged 2015-04-20 21:26:05,lamblin closed 2015-04-20 21:26:05,carriepl head_ref_deleted 2015-06-05 18:45:33

Title: [CRASH] Scan segfault with inconsistent inner graphs
Description:
This PR adds some validation and a test case for the recent segfault issue when the inner graph has inconsistencies. The validation ensures that, for recurrent states, the inner inputs and inner outputs have the same type and that there are no GPU variables in the inputs and/or outputs is the flags in scan_op.info are not set correctly.

This also includes some refactoring of some helper functions in Scan_op to travel between inner and outer variables as well as between inputs and outputs.

Title: [CRASH new backend] Fix comparison between ssize_t and size_t
Description: `*start` and `*stop` are `ssize_t` and `len` is `size_t`. When either `ssize_t` is below 0, is will automatically be cast to `size_t` for the comparison and will thus appear to be incredibly large, making the check pass even if it shouldn't.

Title: [CRASH] Improve shared variable management in Scan
Description:
~~Those checks were added for the sake of completeness in a previous PR but they were not required for any use case known at that time.~~

~~This PR deactivates them for the time being because it appears these checks are causing issues with valid graphs (https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/theano-users/y7Nb8oYRUa0).~~

~~Since they are not required anywhere, they can be deactivated for the time being but we should go back eventually to figure out why.~~

Updated description:
The PR changes the way Scan handles some shared variables as recurrent outputs to make sure the associated and outputs are on the CPU. 

The current way it's implemented would mistakenly have MRG_RandomStreams with an input state on the CPU and the output state on GPU. This wasn't caught by anything but, eventually, through the optimization process, the graph was modified and made consistent so no one ever had any issue with this. The recently-added checks for the consistency of the inner graph caught the inconsistency and that is what caused the crash.

Title: Scan memory reuse
Description:
This PR fixes two bug in the currently deactivated memory pre-allocation feature in Scan and activates it in both the Python and Cython backends. This means that is doesn't fix bugs that are currently occurring but rather it fixes the memory pre-allocation so that we can use it without introducing bugs.

The first bug it fixes comes from an optimization in `GpuDimshuffle` in the cuda gpu backend where, to avoid creating a new array, it can reuse the one it receives as input and alter its attributes, including the `gpudata` attribute. This caused an issue in the old code for the memory pre-allocation because it relied on the assumption that a given CudaNdarray object would always point to the same memory region and that if an Op needed to return a CudaNdarray pointing to a new memory region, it would create a new one and leave the original untouched.

The second bug comes from the SaveMem optimization and the fact that it tries (if it can) to keep a circular buffer only as small as the number of states required at any given iteration to compute the next state. This works without the memory reuse feature because all the outputs of the inner function are computed and then they are put in the buffers. With the memory reuse, since the outputs are stored in the buffers as they are computed by the inner function, the buffers need to be at least 1 element bigger so that the new states can be stored without overwriting the oldest state that is still used in the inner function.

Now, there are added checks to ensure that the pre-allocated array has been reused _and_ that it still points to the same data.

Events: lamblin referenced 2015-05-01 23:05:23,lamblin merged 2015-05-01 23:05:23,lamblin closed 2015-05-01 23:05:23,lamblin head_ref_deleted 2015-05-04 16:10:20

Title: Replace except Class, e -> except Class as e
Description:
**NOTE:** Ideally #2860, #2862, #2864 and #2869 all get merged around the same time, to minimize the number of rebases. I can also consolidate them into one PR if need be.

Python 3 compatibility, old `except E, e` is unsupported in 3.x, but 'as' is supported >= 2.6, etc.

For the record, all it took was

```
find . -name '*.py' -exec sed -i '.bak' 's/^\\( *\\)except \\([^\\(]*\\),/\\1except \\2 as/' {} \\;
find . -name '*.py' -exec sed -i '.bak' 's/^\\( *\\)except \\((.*)\\),/\\1except \\2 as/' {} \\;
```

Title: (#2613, #2747) Add handling of negative axis for Join and GpuJoin
Description:
(#2613, #2747)

Negative axis were automatically handled by numpy implementation inside
Join.{perform,c_code}. However, both Join.grad and
GpuJoin.{perform,c_code,grad} implementations were not thought to take care of
negative axis.

This commit adds convertion of axis when negative such that it is always
positive. Fixing it in Join._make_node_internal also fix GpuJoin at the
same time. Symbolic axis need to be taken care of by adding a
tensor.switch to increment axis when necessary. However, assert_op can
be removed by some optimizer modes and thus exceeding negative axis can
be undetected. Another option is to hardcode asserts in
{Gpu}Join.{perform, c_code} but that means maintaining a similar code
4 times...

Title: Add new scalar and elemwise op erfcx
Description:
op for calculating the scaled complementary error function exp(x_**2)_*erfc(x) in a numerically stable way

This op is useful for calculating various things related to Gaussian distributions, such as truncated moments and expressions involving log(cdf(x)) for large negative values of x. The contributed code very closely follows that of the Erfinv op.

Tested on an EC2 GPU instance. Works for both CPU and GPU.

Title: Downsample: C implementation for average, sum
Description:
Hi. I'd like to propose the following changes to the downsampling code:
- extend the C implementation of Downsample to support `average_inc_pad` and `average_exc_pad`,
- add a new `sum` mode to the Python and C implementations.

The C implementation for the `average_*` modes reuses most of the code from `max`. The `sum` mode is a relatively straightforward extension.

Title: [CRASH] Scan index error
Description:
This is a fix for the segfault issue reported on the theano-users mailing list  (https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/theano-users/ryurT5G6G7M/discussion).

The issue was with the scanOp_pushout_seqs optimization which was trying to push out computation that did not depend on sequences and, therefore, should have been handled by scanOp_pushout_non_seqs.

Title: Move gpu tests from T_Scan to ScanGpuTests
Description:
This PR refactors the gpu tests in test_scan.py to make them more easily usable to test both the cuda and the gpuarray backends.

The tests that can be made to work for both backends are moved to ScanGpuTests and are modified to rely on certain attributes/methods that will manage the interactions with the concrete gpu backend. The classes T_Scan_Cuda and T_Scan_Gpuarray inherit from ScanGpuTests and TestCase and implement these attributes/methods so that the tests will rely on their respective backends.

Some tests were highly cuda specific so they we moved to T_Scan_Cuda instead of ScanGpuTests.

Title: broadcastable option to tensor.alloc
Description:
Added a broadcastable option to tensor.alloc. When `broadcatable=False`, no axis will be set broadcastable even when its dim is 1. The default value is `True`. As an example,

```
In [2]: from theano import tensor
In [3]: a = tensor.alloc(1,1,10)
In [4]: print a.broadcastable
(True, False)
In [5]: b = tensor.alloc(1,1,10,broadcastable=False)
In [6]: print b.broadcastable
(False, False)
In [7]: c = tensor.alloc(1,1,10,broadcastable=True)
In [8]: print c.broadcastable
(True, False)
```

This becomes handy when tensor.alloc is used to initialize a variable passed to the inner scan function as a part of `outputs_info`, since the broadcastable patterns affects the variable filter inside the scan op.

Title: Add opt for gpuarray.GpuElemwise so exponent of pow has same dtype as output
Description: In the gpuarray backend, pow can only be done on inputs that are both float (producing a float output) or both double (producing a double output). Currently, some unit tests for Scan attempt to do `a_float ** an_int16` which raises a compilation error. This optimization adds  a cast to ensure that the exponent has the same dtype as the output to prevent this.

Title: [Bug] Revert dot22->gemm optimization back to dot22->dot22scalar
Description:
The previously done change from dot22->dot22scalar to dot22->gemm had the effect, under some not-fully-understood circumstances,  of duplicating certain Scan nodes and preventing certain optimizations (such as ScanSaveMem) on the duplicates. The result was a drastic increase in memory usage.

The issue should be investigated further and tests added to try and ensure this doesn't occur again but, in the mean time, this fixes this issue which is preventing from people from using the latest version.

Title: [CRASH] Scan index error
Description:
This fixes an IndexError that would occur when running the test case included in the PR. It also removes 3 methods in ScanOp, two of which were never used and one, `get_output_pos()`, which was used in `grad()`. 

The method `get_output_pos()` allowed to travel between inner inputs and inner outputs of recurrent states. I removed it because : 
- It only worked for variables representing recurrent states (I added another method which can deal with any inner input)
- The method's documentation implied that it could be used for any inner input even it that wasn't the case. This was confusing and just begged for the function to be misused by an unsuspecting user.
- The method WAS actually misused in ScanOp.grad() where it was, by mistake, called to travel between inner inputs and **outer** outputs. This didn't cause any error when taking the gradient of a user-defined Scan node because, in the absence of mitmots, the number of inner outputs associated with recurrent states is equal to the number of outer outputs associated with recurrent states. When taking the gradient of a grad-scan, this assumption breaks and leads to the crash in some cases.

Title: Make local_dimshuffle_lift go through many nodes
Description:
Make local_dimshuffle_lift go through many nodes by recursively calling itself. This commit is following the patch provided by Fred here ( https://github.com/Theano/Theano/issues/2971 ). 

I tested it with following code.

```
import theano                                                                                   
import theano.tensor as T

v = T.vector()
m = T.matrix()
out0 = (v+m).T
out = (out0 + 42).T
theano.config.optimizer_verbose = True
f = theano.function([v, m], out)
```

The output before this optimization as follows,

```
local_dimshuffle_lift DimShuffle{1,0}.0 Elemwise{add,no_inplace}.0
local_dimshuffle_lift DimShuffle{1,0}.0 Elemwise{add,no_inplace}.0
MergeOptimizer tan.0 tan.0
MergeOptimizer sqr.0 sqr.0
...... { MergeOptimizers for many times, ignored here}
MergeOptimizer true_div.0 true_div.0
MergeOptimizer tan.0 tan.0
constant_folding DimShuffle{x,x}.0 TensorConstant{(1, 1) of 42}
local_upcast_elemwise_constant_inputs Elemwise{add,no_inplace}.0 Elemwise{add,no_inplace}.0
local_dimshuffle_lift DimShuffle{1,0}.0 Elemwise{add,no_inplace}.0
local_dimshuffle_lift DimShuffle{1,0}.0 DimShuffle{0,x}.0
local_add_canonizer Elemwise{add,no_inplace}.0 Elemwise{add,no_inplace}.0
local_dimshuffle_lift DimShuffle{1,0}.0 DimShuffle{x,0}.0
local_dimshuffle_lift DimShuffle{1,0}.0 <TensorType(float64, matrix)>
constant_folding DimShuffle{x,x}.0 TensorConstant{(1, 1) of 42.0}
dimshuffle_as_view DimShuffle{x,0}.0 InplaceDimShuffle{x,0}.0
```

The output after is as follows,

```
local_dimshuffle_lift DimShuffle{1,0}.0 Elemwise{add,no_inplace}.0
MergeOptimizer DimShuffle{x,x}.0 DimShuffle{x,x}.0
local_upcast_elemwise_constant_inputs Elemwise{add,no_inplace}.0 Elemwise{add,no_inplace}.0
MergeOptimizer TensorConstant{42} TensorConstant{42}
local_add_canonizer Elemwise{add,no_inplace}.0 Elemwise{add,no_inplace}.0
MergeOptimizer DimShuffle{x,0}.0 DimShuffle{x,0}.0
MergeOptimizer tan.0 tan.0
MergeOptimizer sqr.0 sqr.0
...... { MergeOptimizers for many times, ignored here}
MergeOptimizer true_div.0 true_div.0
MergeOptimizer tan.0 tan.0
constant_folding DimShuffle{x,x}.0 TensorConstant{(1, 1) of 42.0}
dimshuffle_as_view DimShuffle{x,0}.0 InplaceDimShuffle{x,0}.0
```

Title: Add theano.tensor.nnet.relu function
Description:
As discussed in #2698, this adds a `theano.tensor.nnet.relu` function providing an optimized formulation of the linear rectifier and leaky linear rectifier at least for GPUs, with the potential to be extended with a different formulation for CPUs or even a ReLU Op in future.

/edit: I'm not sure about the docs, how can I test them?

Title: Initial work on issue #3018.
Description:
I've submitted some preliminary code. I'm not very sure about my implementation so far, because many optimizations move around the graph is funky ways and call functions I don't understand.
Maybe we can talk about some of this.

Also, some optimizations, which reprocess outputs don't really need to have their stack traces copied over (I think). For example: 
- local_lift_transpose_through_dot
- local_dimshuffle_no_inplace_at_canonicalize
- local_fill_to_alloc (first two returns at least)

These take the inputs to the node and output another tensor variable. The stacktrace should be constructed appropriately through the rest of the code.

Title: Port of the cudnn code for the gpuarray backend
Description:
This ports the current cudnn code we have for the cuda backend over to the gpuarray one.

I've made it so the first commit just copies all the code and then the subsequent ones adapt it.

Some of the surrounding code had to be fixed also so there is a bit more than just straight adapting.

All of tests/test_dnn.py passes locally.

Title: Speed up Scan optimizations
Description:
@lamblin @carriepl @nouiz 
I have done some easy optimizations in the scan_opt.py. Most of the operations that can be done in constant time by using set or dictionary, previously was being done in linear time inside the loop. It was a bit slow because of that. 

There are a few other changes that I want to do as well. 

These changes speedup by more than 100 secs for a computational graph that was taking more than 900 secs to compile.

General
- [x] Write real tests, current 'tests' are just copied from tensor.nnet, not sure if they make any sense

- [ ] Move code out of sandbox and into final location (tensor.nnet?)

C code

- [x] write cormm for cpu
- [x] float 32 and 64 versions

Theano
- [x] write ops
  - [x] BaseCpuCorrMM
  - [x] CpuCorrMM
  - [x] CpuCorrMM_gradWeights
  - [x] CpuCorrMM_gradInputs

Later PRs
- Write optimization to swap conv ops (waiting on #2665)
- Add 'same' mode for cpu and gpu versions

Title: added the shared variable zero fn.
Description:
I was using this function for a while for myself. It is very similar to what torch.tensor:zero function does:
https://github.com/torch/torch7/blob/master/doc/tensor.md#self-zero

This is just a syntactic sugar. I find this more readable than doing get_value and then set_value to reset a shared variable to zero in my code. 

If that PR gets through, I have a few other functions like that which I can make PR for too.

Title: [BUG] Fix invalid optimization for product of multiplication
Description:
Optimization local_sum_prod_mul_by_scalar had behavior : 
prod(scalar \\* smth) -> scalar \\* prod(smth)
prod(-smth) -> -prod(smth)

when it should have been : 
prod(scalar \\* smth) -> scalar *\\* size(smth) \\* prod(smth)
prod(-smth) -> (-1) *\\* size(smth) \\* prod(smth)

Title: Performance improvement for GpuCrossentropySoftmaxArgmax1HotWithBias
Description:
After a bit of profiling this op turned out to be a massive bottleneck in training a smaller feedforward network with a large-ish (10000 class) softmax output layer, taking 40 to 60% of the total time, much more than any of the dot22 / gemm linear algebra ops which really should be the bottleneck.

On investigation it turned out the GPU kernel for this op was only using a single thread, with a TODO to fix it. This commit implements that TODO. This op now only takes around 6% of the total time for me. It could probably be optimised further (e.g. via hierarchical / multi-stage reductions) but I think this is worth submitting.

Tagging @jaberg as it looks like this was your code originally. It's my first theano contribution and I'm relatively new to CUDA so let me know if you notice anything wrong. The relevant tests still pass at least.

Incidentally the CPU implementation of this op seems suspiciously slow too, although I didn't focus on optimising that because I'm mainly using GPU.

Title: Remove the restriction on zero target dimensions when reshaping a CudaNdarray
Description:
Fixes #3175 for me.

I couldn't see any obvious problems with removing this restriction (which isn't applied by the CPU backend). But perhaps there was some cuda-specific reason for the stricter restriction here?

There was a commit (https://github.com/Theano/Theano/commit/23fa09f02d731ca0a5437772cf6118ca16c542c9) made to permit reshaping of zero-size arrays before, which looks like it fixed this issue but was partially undone again at some point in a merge.

Title: Allow slicing of tensor variables to return symbolic shape refs
Description:
This addresses https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/theano-users/AUuHNstlVYY.  It allows for this kind of stuff to work:

``` Python
>>> import theano
>>> import numpy as np
>>> import theano.tensor as T
>>> x = T.tensor4('x')
>>> a, b = x.shape[:2]
>>> a.eval({x: np.zeros((5, 4, 3, 2), dtype=theano.config.floatX)})
array(5)
>>> a = x.shape[3:10]
>>> a.eval({x: np.zeros((5, 4, 3, 2), dtype=theano.config.floatX)})
array([2])
```
Events: craffel head_ref_force_pushed 2015-07-23 20:53:17,craffel head_ref_force_pushed 2015-07-24 15:54:47,nouiz referenced 2015-07-25 00:05:48,nouiz merged 2015-07-25 00:05:48,nouiz closed 2015-07-25 00:05:48,craffel head_ref_deleted 2015-08-11 00:11:27

Title: Cudnn 3d benchmark
Description:
task description:
## What you need to do is make an optimization that isn't enabled by default, but if enable by the user, would convert the op GpuCorrMM3d to GpuDnnConv3d, and the same for the 2 grad ops. You need to test that by default, we don't introduce it and that if we include the opt mode.including('opt_name'), we do it. Also, double check the timming, currently, previous pre-release version had the cudnn version slower then the cormm version. That is why we don't want to enable it by default. But it use less memory, so we want to allow this option.

So far I've done the part of replacing GpuCorr3dMM with GpuDnnConv3d, not with the grads yet. I need to lean more about the difference between those grad ops in order to transform one to the other.

Title: ENH: allow numpy.*(theano_var) to build a graph
Description:
This PR follows the pattern demonstrated in #3112 to allow more numpy functions to build a graph in a manner that is convenient for PyMC3 users. 

This includes everything listed in https://github.com/Theano/Theano/issues/3040#issuecomment-114097347 except for the following: `degrees, fabs, radians, rint`.  I suspect that these will not be missed, since they all have simple alternatives.

I think that this can close issue #3040.

Title: Integrate the latest version of CNMEM
Description:
This version comes with two fixes.

1/ Fix a warning due to the visibility attribute needed by Theano.
We changed const char\\* CNMEM_API to const char CNMEM_API\\* in the
declaration of cnmemGetErrorString to have the attribute between
char and star. It fixes the warning.

2/ Fix a compilation issue with CUDA 5.0 due to the missing
cudaStreamGetFlags function. It is #defined out when the Runtime
is less than 5.5 (5050 version).

Title: Fix outdated description of border_mode in GpuCorrMM constructor
Description: #2259 changed `BaseGpuCorrMM` to accept custom padding in `border_mode` and warn against using `pad`, but the docstring of `GpuCorrMM` was not updated accordingly. This PR updates the docstring to match the implementation. It removes the warning that `border_mode='full'` can be slower than `GpuCorrMM_gradInputs` because that would need to go with a lengthy explanation on how to use the latter instead, it's not _always_ slower, and it's probably just confusing end users.

Title: CuDNN v3
Description:
Add support for CuDNN V3.
This includes : 
-Wrapping the 3d convolution
-Supporting the new features for selecting the most efficient convolution implementation either by timing them or by guessing according to heuristics.
-Support for the new log-softmax implementation (integrated into existing op for CuDNN softmax and inserted via optimizations)
-Adding tests for the corresponding features

Title: fix dnn_conv() direction_hint check
Description: Commit 05dc20d introduced a check for `direction_hint` in `dnn_conv()` that is too strict. `dnn_conv()` is regularly called with `direction_hint='bprop inputs'`, and the meta-optimizer may also call it with `direction_hint='forward!'` (the latter was supposed to change, but in discussing it we decided to wait until #2665 is finished, which seemed to be within a few weeks at that time).

Title: Fix GpuDnnConvGradI not being inserted automatically
Description:
#3245 rendered part of the `local_conv_dnn()` graph optimizer inoperable (due to an assertion on `direction_hint` in `dnn_conv()` being too strict, as described in #3248) and slow (due to `GpuDnnConvGradI` not being used any more, as described in #3249). This PR fixes both in one go, going for the third solution outlined in #3249.

It also resolves #2644, via the first solution proposed in https://github.com/Theano/Theano/issues/2644#issuecomment-84032628.

Fixes #3249. Closes #3248.

Title: Fix metaoptimizer for cudnn
Description:
The convolution meta-optimizer currently fails for cuDNN with: `theano.function was asked to create a function computing outputs given certain inputs, but the provided input variable at index 0 is not part of the computational graph needed to compute the outputs: <CudaNdarrayType(float32, 4D)>.`
That's because it collects required inputs from the original GpuConv Op prior to applying any optimizers, and it may happen that the optimizers render one of the inputs unneeded (I haven't looked into this, but I assume it could be due to the output shape computation or something).
This PR fixes this by allowing the function compiled for timing the replaced Op to accept inputs it doesn't actually need (`on_unused_input='ignore'`).

Title: enable dots in section names

This patch corrects these issue.

Title: Early detection of device capability for proper cuda_ndarray compilation
Description:
Dear developers,

upon a fresh installation of **theano** I ran into the problem where there was a mismatch between the architecture on which **cuda_ndarray** library was compiled and the architecture setting of compiled apply nodes. Basically calling some kernel functions from **cuda_ndarray.cu** (specifically **k_elemwise_unary_rowmajor_copy**) resulted in "invalid device function" error. Due to hardware reasons I have to use CUDA driver 6.5, which still supports old devices like the one I have: GeForce 320M (SM version 1.2).

The problem hid in the fact that the code for device capability detection resides in **cuda_ndarray** module, which had to be compiled upon the very first import of theano. The compilation in **__ init __.py** of **theano/sandbox/cuda** invokes **nvcc_compiler.compile_str()**, which in turn tries to detect device capabilities using the yet nonexistent **cuda_ndarray** module, and obviously fails. Thus the compilation of **cuda_ndarray** defaulted to some architecture of nvcc compiler, which turned out to be backwards incompatible with sm12.

That is why is patched the **__ init __.py** code so that it first tries to compile a lightweight module for early device capability detection (**cuda_devquery.cu**), and then, upon success, uses the correct device dependent flags for **cuda_ndarray** compilation.

I had to modify some extra code in **__ init __.py**, specifically the parts where CUDA availability is detected and where the compiled module is checked for being correct and up-to-date (former **try_import()**).

Please consider this patch request and send your remarks and suggestions.

Ivan

Title: python 3 fix in dnn.py
Description:
In python 3, map returns a map object iterator rather than a list, which here gets consumed by min, leaving pad_desc empty.
This bug was just introduced with the update to cudnn v3.

Title: Small visual changes (blue color)
Description:
Ive added the key Output to the dict colorCodes in order to be able
to changes the blue color of Theano graph node which is not well
visible. Personally, I used the 'Output': '#87CEFA'  color code calling
pydotprint().

An alternative correction should be to replace blue by '#87CEFA.
Its up to you

Title: [WIP] CpuCorrMM closes #3026 - redux
Description:
First PR was in strange state. Local commit history was different than github history and I couldn't reconcile them. Trying again...

CPU implementation of the CorrMM style convolutions for #3026.

General
- [x] Write real tests, current 'tests' are just copied from tensor.nnet, not sure if they make any sense
- [x] Get tests to pass
- [x] Move code out of sandbox and into final location (tensor.nnet?)

C code
- [x] write im2col and col2im for cpu
- [x] write cormm for cpu
- [x] float 32 and 64 versions

Theano
- [x] write ops
  - [x] BaseCpuCorrMM
  - [x] CpuCorrMM
  - [x] CpuCorrMM_gradWeights
  - [x] CpuCorrMM_gradInputs

Later PRs
- Write optimization to swap conv ops (waiting on #2665)

Title: Prevent ScanSaveMem from creating 0-steps scans.
Description:
After discussion with @lamblin and @abergeron, we agreed on the fix being to prevent ScanSaveMem to reduce below 1 the number of steps a Scan will run. 

The alternative was making Scan support having 0 steps at execution time but that would still involve running the Scan for at least one iteration so that the output shapes would be known : even if the scan is supposed to run 0 steps and return empty outputs, these outputs still need to have the right shape. For recurrent states, the shape can be obtained from the initial states but for non-recurrent states, the inner function has to be executed at least once to know their shapes.

Title: Correct config.lib.cnmem name in documentation
Description: It's a trivial change, but the CNMeM configuration option was named `lib.cnmem` instead of `config.lib.cnmem` in the documentation. As I hadn't heard about the `lib` prefix before, I thought it should mean `config.cnmem` and thus my first attempt was to use `THEANO_FLAGS=cnmem=.3`, which didn't work. This PR makes it unambiguous.

Title: map_variables
Description:
(Work in progress on #3177 , do not merge)

Now the replacement descends into scan nodes. For some reason that I don't understand, I need to keep track of those scan nodes that I have already replaced. Otherwise the local optimizer will be called again and again on the replaced node. Changing the order from out_to_in to in_to_out doesn't change that.

I'll sort out the mess of imports later.

(The other pull request was from my master and got contaminated with unrelated commits; I'll use this one from now on.)

Title: d3viz: Interactive visualization of Theano compute graphs
Description:
`d3viz` extends Theanos printing module
to interactively visualize compute graphs. Instead of creating a static
picture, it creates an HTML file, which can be opened with any
web-browser. `d3viz` allows
-  to zoom to different regions and to move graphs via drag and drop,
-  to position nodes both manually and automatically,
-  to retrieve additional information about nodes and edges such as
  their data type or definition in the source code,
-  to edit node labels,
-  to visualizing profiling information, and
-  to explore nested graphs such as OpFromGraph nodes.

This pull request includes the fully documented and tested `d3viz` module, as well as an user guide with examples.

Title: Use the libgpuarray APIs to manage GPU code compilation, execution, etc.
Description:
Currently, the gpuarray back end of Theano uses a mixture of libgpuarray and nvcc, which is slow for online compilation.  We can speed up the GPU code compilation using libgpuarray API alone without nvcc, especially when libgpuarray is built with the nvrtc support (see https://github.com/Theano/libgpuarray/pull/72).

This hopefully helps managing GPU related code in Theano and libgpuarray by having vendor specific implementation only in libgpuarray.
Changed Files: theano/sandbox/gpuarray/nnet.py theano/sandbox/gpuarray/kernel_codegen.py theano/sandbox/gpuarray/conv_full_kernel.cu theano/sandbox/gpuarray/conv.py theano/sandbox/gpuarray/conv.cu theano/sandbox/gpuarray/conv_kernel.cu theano/sandbox/gpuarray/neighbours.py theano/sandbox/gpuarray/subtensor.py theano/sandbox/gpuarray/elemwise.py theano/sandbox/gpuarray/basic_ops.py
